title: 109_s3559
content: The Act titled "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" enhances penalties for fraud related to major disaster or emergency benefits. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" increases penalties for fraud involving major disaster or emergency benefits, including falsifying information or making fraudulent statements related to disaster relief or emergency declarations. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" increases penalties for fraud involving major disaster or emergency benefits, including falsifying information or making fraudulent statements related to disaster relief or emergency declarations. Contractors working on US contracts may face fines or imprisonment for up to 30 years if involved in fraudulent activities affecting interstate commerce or government benefits. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" increases penalties for fraud related to major disasters or emergencies. It includes wire, radio, and television fraud as well as mail fraud during presidentially declared disasters or emergencies. The Act also directs the Sentencing Commission to take action. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to increase penalties for fraud or theft offenses related to major disasters or emergencies. They must also submit an explanation of their actions to Congress and provide policy recommendations for combating these offenses. The United States Sentencing Commission is mandated to enhance penalties for fraud or theft offenses linked to major disasters or emergencies. They must ensure consistency with other directives, consider aggravating or mitigating circumstances, make necessary changes to sentencing guidelines, and align with the purposes of sentencing. The Commission has emergency authority to promulgate guidelines or amendments within 30 days of the enactment of the Act.
